author: By Ava Sasani
title: Former Georgetown Tennis Coach Sentenced to More Than 2 Years in Varsity Blues Case
description: The sentence is the harshest punishment yet in the college admissions scandal.
content: A former Georgetown University head tennis coach who pleaded guilty last fall to accepting bribes to help prospective students gain admission to the school was sentenced Friday to more than two years in prison, according to the U.S. attorney’s office for the District of Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Ukraine dreams of rebuilding the world’s largest airplane. Can Richard Branson help?
description: A Virgin Group spokesperson said the effort would turn to finding ways the international community could support the project.
content: Four months ago, at the beginning of the war, countless Ukrainians were demoralized when they learned that the world’s largest cargo airplane, built in Ukraine, was destroyed in a fierce battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: The Federal Government Subsidizes Abortions. Will That Last?
description: Individuals can often use health insurance or flexible spending accounts to pay for abortions or deduct the cost on tax returns. Congress might weigh in.
content: In the United States, you can get a tax deduction for your abortion if your overall health care expenses are high enough. That didn’t change with the Supreme Court’s ruling last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in July
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of July’s most promising new titles.
content: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: The Long Path to Reclaim Abortion Rights
description: The Supreme Court decision to reverse Roe, far from settling the matter, instead has launched court and political battles across the states likely to go on for years.
content: Attempting to recover from their staggering loss in the Supreme Court, abortion rights groups have mounted a multilevel legal and political attack aimed at blocking and reversing abortion bans in courts and at ballot boxes across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Repeatedly Strikes Ukraine’s Civilians. There’s Always an Excuse.
description: The Kremlin’s explanations have sometimes satisfied the Russian people, but they fall apart under closer scrutiny abroad.
content: Since late February, when Russia began pummeling Ukraine with missiles and artillery on a scale unseen in Europe for decades, civilian deaths have been as inevitable as the Russian excuses that follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Karan Deep Singh
title: Japan Swelters Through a Punishing Heat Wave
description: Temperatures in Tokyo surpassed 95 degrees for the eighth straight day on Saturday, a streak seen only once before since 1875.
content: TOKYO — Japan is enduring one of its worst heat waves on record, raising concern about potential power shortages amid surging demand, even as officials urged people to keep their air-conditioners running to ward off heat stroke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins, Chelsia Rose Marcius and William K. Rashbaum
title: Baby’s Father Arrested in Shooting of Woman Who Was Walking Stroller
description: Azsia Johnson, 20, was shot to death on a quiet section of 95th Street on Wednesday evening. The father of their child was arrested on Friday evening and charged with murder.
content: A 22-year-old man was arrested in connection with the death of Azsia Johnson, a 20-year-old mother who was fatally shot at point blank range on Wednesday as she pushed her 3-month-old daughter in a stroller while on a walk on the Upper East Side, the police announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: How to Watch Fourth of July Fireworks in New York City
description: From the Macy’s display to Coney Island, here are the spots across the city where you can celebrate Independence Day with dazzling light displays.
content: While a number of cities are canceling Fourth of July fireworks this year because of staff and supply shortages, among other reasons, New York City will still celebrate the holiday with a fiery show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Ben Dooley
title: Japan’s Secret to Taming the Coronavirus: Peer Pressure
description: The country has never mandated masks or vaccinations, but it’s evaded the worst of Covid, thanks to a fear of public shaming and the “self restraint police.”
content: TOKYO — To understand how Japan has fared better than most of the world in containing the dire consequences of the coronavirus pandemic, consider Mika Yanagihara, who went shopping for flowers this past week in central Tokyo. Even when walking outside in temperatures in the mid-90s, she kept the lower half of her face fully covered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: A Guide to the Weekend
description: Recommendations for a summer holiday — movies, podcasts, “Stranger Things” and cobbler.
content: The most reliable way I’ve found to discover books I love is by seeking out the recommendations of writers whose work I admire. So when I saw that Patrick Radden Keefe, the author of the riveting “Empire of Pain,” was discussing his favorite writers in The Times Book Review, I broke out my note-taking app to add Emmanuel Carrère’s “The Adversary” to my ever-lengthening list of titles to read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Russia Steps Up Pace of Missile Attacks on Residential Targets
description: The Russians’ growing use of imprecise Soviet-era missiles to terrorize civilians reflects the daunting outlook of its offensive despite incremental gains, analysts say.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — An attack on a shopping mall on Monday, killing 19 civilians. A missile strike on a sleepy resort town on Friday, claiming the lives of at least 21 residents. Cluster bombs on Saturday hit a residential block in an industrial hub, leaving four dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Tick or Tock
description: Evan Kalish breaks into Saturday with an artful challenge.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid is a neat accomplishment. It’s Evan Kalish’s first Saturday puzzle, and he has now hit for the cycle as a constructor of at least one daily puzzle for all seven days of the week, plus a variety puzzle (a vowel-less crossword, if you’re interested in trng smthng nw).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Expansion Pack
description: Tom McCoy's Sunday puzzle might be hard to get a handle on, but it’s worth it!
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This grid marks the Sunday return of Tom McCoy after a far-too-long absence — nearly two years — that likely corresponds to a period of intense study. Mr. McCoy, who lives in Wexford, Pa., recently defended his doctoral dissertation in cognitive science at Johns Hopkins University, on the subject of how language is represented in artificial intelligence systems and what that tells us about language in humans. This fall, he will begin a postdoctoral program at Princeton, which might be easier to juggle with crossword construction (probably wishful thinking on my part).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Palestinians Give U.S. Experts Bullet That Killed Journalist
description: Officials believe that the bullet, which killed Shireen Abu Akleh, could hold essential clues as to who is responsible for her death.
content: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian Authority has handed over to a team of American investigators the bullet it says killed the Palestinian American journalist Shireen Abu Akleh, Palestinian officials said on Saturday, in a move meant to clarify the circumstances of the reporter’s death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Webb Telescope Will Look for Signs of Life Way Out There
description: The first question astronomers want to answer about exoplanets: Do they have atmospheres friendly to life?
content: This month will mark a new chapter in the search for extraterrestrial life, when the most powerful space telescope yet built will start spying on planets that orbit other stars. Astronomers hope that the James Webb Space Telescope will reveal whether some of those planets harbor atmospheres that might support life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Long Live the Theater’ in Mariupol, Now Gone
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 2, 2022.
content: “There is a saying: ‘The king is dead. Long live the king.’ So, the theater died. Long live the theater.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Ukraine’s Lesia Tsurenko Plays Tennis for the Money
description: She used to compete because she loved tennis, but now Tsurenko wants to win as much prize money as possible to help people in her war-torn country.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Lesia Tsurenko’s Wimbledon campaign ended Friday during a match in which her head was someplace else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: When Where You Work Determines if You Can Get an Abortion
description: After the Dobbs v. Jackson decision, many women are discovering that their employer can shape major decisions in their lives even more than it did a week ago.
content: When Breanna Dietrich was 18 and working at a restaurant in West Virginia, she got pregnant. The father was a man she knew she wouldn’t marry. She considered getting an abortion. But the nearest clinic was four hours away and she couldn’t afford to take off work — so she had the baby girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Searching for Gold, Miners Discover a Frozen Baby Mammoth
description: Experts believe that the woolly mammoth, unearthed in the Klondike gold fields of the Yukon of Canada, had been preserved in the frozen ground for more than 30,000 years.
content: About a half-hour before his lunch break one June morning, Travis Mudry was operating an excavator and digging through permafrost in the Klondike gold fields of the Yukon in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Ill Prepared for Combat, Volunteers Die in Battles Far From Home
description: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.
content: RUDNE, Ukraine — Yurii Brukhal, an electrician by trade, did not have a very dangerous role when he volunteered for Ukraine’s territorial defense forces at the start of the war. He was assigned to make deliveries and staff a checkpoint in the relative safety of his sleepy village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Skyrocketing Global Fuel Prices Threaten Livelihoods and Social Stability
description: Around the world, from South Asia and Africa to Europe and Latin America, the cost of filling a car’s tank, getting to work and cooking dinner has spiked.
content: “NO ES SUFICIENTE” — It’s not enough. That was the message protest leaders in Ecuador delivered to the country’s president this past week after he said he would lower the price of both regular gas and diesel by 10 cents in response to riotous demonstrations over soaring fuel and food prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Sales Slow as the Pandemic Hobbles Production
description: The decline in deliveries by the electric carmaker in the second quarter was the first drop since the beginning of 2020. The main culprit was factory shutdowns in China.
content: Tesla said Saturday that vehicle deliveries from April through June fell 18 percent from the first quarter of the year, a rare slowdown for the company caused by production problems in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: What to Do Now to Prepare for the Next Recession
description: Rushing in to confront a crisis is always better than letting it simply unfold.
content: In the face of rising inflation, the Federal Reserve is trying to cool down the economy, raising interest rates by 0.75 percentage point in June, the biggest increase since 1994. Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, has vowed to try to engineer a “soft landing” — in which demand drops, bringing prices down, without tipping the economy into a recession and throwing hundreds of thousands of Americans out of their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: A Mother and Her 3 Children Are Found Dead in a Minnesota Lake
description: The authorities said the case was being investigated as a “possible triple murder-suicide” and was believed to be connected to another suicide on Friday.
content: The bodies of a mother and her three children, two boys and one girl, were recovered in a lake outside Saint Paul, Minn., and the authorities said they were investigating it as a “possible triple murder-suicide.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart
title: Did the Supreme Court Open the Door to Reviving One of Its Worst Decisions?
description: Lochner v. New York, a 1905 decision on labor law, is imprinted on today’s law students as an example of bad jurisprudence. But those old days could be returning.
content: In the annals of the Supreme Court, few opinions have been more reviled than the 1905 decision in Lochner v. New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: Let’s Not Pretend We’re Keeping Our Promises on Asylum
description: The most powerful countries decided that people were entitled to seek asylum. Now they undermine those promises without consequence.
content: In this restive age of unprecedented human displacement, 100 million people have fled disaster and oppression to try their luck in a world that’s increasingly tired of dealing with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Spurred by the Supreme Court, a Nation Divides Along a Red-Blue Axis
description: On abortion, climate change, guns and much more, two Americas — one liberal, one conservative — are moving in opposite directions.
content: Pressed by Supreme Court decisions diminishing rights that liberals hold dear and expanding those cherished by conservatives, the United States appears to be drifting apart into separate nations, with diametrically opposed social, environmental and health policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: The Democrat Who’s Flipping the Campaign Script
description: A candidate for Congress is speaking out against the government red tape that is reviled in parts of rural America.
content: ROCK HALL, Md. — When Dave Harden decided to run for Congress as a Democrat on Maryland’s conservative Eastern Shore, a friend gave him a piece of free advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: On a Long Climb to the Top, She Makes Short Work of an Opponent
description: Kayla Harrison easily dispatched her rival in their Professional Fighters League bout on Friday. She wants to take on the best women in mixed martial arts, but contracts stand in the way.
content: Kayla Harrison’s second bout of the Professional Fighters League regular season unfolded as predictably as the betting odds — tilted heavily in her favor — suggested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Thousands of Flights Are Delayed or Canceled as Holiday Travel Kicks Off
description: Airlines, dealing with bad weather and staffing shortages, struggle to keep up with high demand over the July 4 weekend.
content: Travelers across the country faced the prospect of canceled or delayed flights on Saturday as airlines and airports dealt with a combination of high demand, bad weather and staffing shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: N.Y. Beaches Step Up Shark Patrols, Adding Drones, Trackers and Tourniquets
description: Amid an increase in shark sightings, lifeguards are increasing patrols and adopting new strategies, but marine experts say “the danger to people is infinitesimal.”
content: LIDO BEACH, N.Y. — It was a classic early summer Friday at Point Lookout Beach on Long Island, with beachgoers frolicking in the frothy waves and basking under the sunny skies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bruce Katz, Pioneer of the Walking Shoe, Is Dead at 75
description: A third-generation shoe manufacturer, he built Rockport with his father and, before selling it to Reebok, campaigned to turn walking into a fitness movement.
content: Bruce Katz, who with his father started the Rockport Shoe Company in 1971 and established walking shoes as a vibrant footwear category, died on June 26 in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Tropical Storm Colin Expected to Weaken After Dousing the Carolinas
description: Colin could be downgraded to a tropical depression on Saturday night or Sunday, and the system was expected to dissipate by Sunday night, forecasters said.
content: Tropical Storm Colin formed early on Saturday morning just off the coast of South Carolina, becoming the third named storm of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season and threatening to drench outdoor activities over the long Independence Day weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani and Edgar Sandoval
title: Uvalde Schools Police Chief Resigns From City Council
description: Pete Arredondo announced he was stepping down “to minimize further distractions.”
content: Pete Arredondo, the chief of the school district police force in Uvalde, Texas, resigned as a member of the Uvalde City Council on Friday amid continued outrage over the slow police response to a shooting at Robb Elementary School in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Brittney Griner’s Detention in Moscow Is Latest in Hostage Diplomacy
description: The United States believes the charges against the basketball star are spurious and tied to American support of Ukraine.
content: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. athlete facing criminal drug charges in Russia, may be merely the latest victim of a practice so common it has its own name: hostage diplomacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Ukraine accuses Russia of dropping white phosphorus on Snake Island after its retreat.
description: Some observers speculated that the strike was a move to destroy equipment that Russia had abandoned on the island and to complicate any future Ukrainian presence there.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s army has accused Russia of dropping incendiary white phosphorus on Snake Island on Friday, the day after Moscow’s forces retreated from the strategic rocky outcrop on the southwestern part of the Black Sea that is key to the Kremlin’s war aims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Prager
title: Seeing Norma: The Conflicted Life of the Woman at the Center of Roe v. Wade
description: Norma McCorvey, the plaintiff in the case that made abortion legal, struggled with her role. Her personal papers offer insight into her life, her thinking — and her continued relevance.
content: Norma McCorvey, the Jane Roe at the center of Roe v. Wade, was an imperfect plaintiff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Swiatek, the World No. 1, Falls at Wimbledon, Ending a Long Win Streak
description: Frustrated by low bounces on the grass courts that took away her most powerful weapons, the top-seeded women’s singles player lost in straight sets to Alizé Cornet of France.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Iga Swiatek, the world No. 1 and the top seed at Wimbledon, did something she had not done in more than four months Saturday. She lost a tennis match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saskia Solomon
title: His Union Went on Strike. His Interviews Went Viral.
description: At a time of rampant inflation and wage stagnation, Mick Lynch, the force behind Britain’s largest railway strikes in three decades, has found success that has surprised even his colleagues.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson has branded him a “union baron,” but Mick Lynch, the union leader who is orchestrating the largest railway strikes in Britain in three decades, has emerged from work stoppages that disrupted the plans of millions of people as an unexpected media sensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: In City Where ‘Europe Starts,’ Ethnic Russians Start Questioning Putin’s War
description: Narva, in northeastern Estonia, is the E.U.’s most ethnically Russian city, with a population supportive of President Vladimir Putin. But the conflict in Ukraine has set off a “mental war” between old and young.
content: NARVA, Estonia — Like many of the ethnic Russians who live along Estonia’s eastern border with Russia, Stanislava Larchenko could not believe that President Vladimir V. Putin had gone on a killing spree in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Prove That I Can Pay the Rent if I Don’t Have a Monthly Salary?
description: For seniors, recent graduates and new hires, finding a home in this market without pay stubs is hard, but not impossible.
content: Q: I’m a retiree with no income but significant liquidity, and I’m wondering how a person without a traditional source of income can qualify for an apartment when landlords typically require renters to show proof that they earn 40 times the monthly rent. I have to believe that mine is not an uncommon situation. What are other ways I can prove to a prospective landlord that I can pay the rent?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Gridlock in Congress Has Amplified the Power of the Supreme Court
description: What was once a dialogue between the branches has become almost entirely one-sided, with the justices accumulating clout at lawmakers’ expense.
content: WASHINGTON — On the last day of a turbulent term that included rulings on what the Constitution has to say about abortion, guns and religion, the Supreme Court issued another sort of decision, one that turned on the words of the Clean Air Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: In Pakistan, a Leader in Trans Rights, Reality Is Slower to Change Than Law
description: Four years after the country became one of the few to protect transgender people’s rights in statute, violence against them has surged and discrimination remains common.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Four years ago, Pakistan stepped to the forefront of transgender rights worldwide, enacting a law that prohibits discrimination against transgender people in schools, workplaces and public settings, and guarantees them the right to choose their gender on official documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Emile Ducke
title: Ukrainian students are hopeful and defiant as they graduate amid war.
description: For these students, this coming-of-age moment amid the war is especially poignant.
content: UZHHOROD, Ukraine — The teenagers, all wearing white sashes with the word “graduate” draped across them, clustered together and laughed as they walked through the Old City looking for somewhere to go out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Kentucky Man Shoots 6 Officers, Killing 3, Police Say
description: The authorities say the suspect, Lance P. Storz, 49, had barricaded himself in his home in Allen, Ky., a town so small it lacks its own police force.
content: Three law enforcement officers were killed and three other officers were shot on Thursday night after a man barricaded in his home opened fire with a rifle in Allen, Ky., a rural town so small that it lacks its own police force, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Inflation Is Posing 19 Problems for One Central Bank
description: After more than a decade of worrying about low inflation, the European Central Bank is trying to tackle the problem of high inflation across the eurozone’s economies.
content: SINTRA, Portugal — For central bankers, the world has changed abruptly. After more than a decade of low inflation and interest rates, policymakers are now in an environment of high inflation, where there isn’t time for ponderous decisions, only swift and decisive action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Supreme Court Marshal Asks Officials to End Protests at Justices’ Homes
description: One official criticized the request, saying that the federal government was primarily responsible for ensuring the safety of justices and their families.
content: WASHINGTON — The chief security officer of the Supreme Court has asked that Virginia and Maryland officials enforce laws that would prohibit protests outside the homes of justices after weeks of demonstrations favoring abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Will Reactionaries Impose a Red-State Social Order on the Rest of Us?
description: The Supreme Court has freed Republican-led states to try extend their authority beyond their borders.
content: One way to understand the work of the Republican Party and its six-member majority on the Supreme Court is to think about the American political system in terms of its defensive and offensive potential. Here, a historical example is in order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: The Republican War on Sex
description: In the America where I came of age, I was told my life was worth more than my ability to have babies. And my sexuality was nothing to be ashamed of.
content: One day I hope to become a mother. But for now I have sex just because I like it. Sex is fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Texas Supreme Court Lifts Freeze on Abortion Ban
description: The decision, overturning a lower court ruling that had temporarily blocked the ban, allowed a 1925 law to take effect.
content: The Texas Supreme Court allowed a 1925 law banning abortion to take effect late on Friday night, overturning a lower court ruling that had temporarily blocked it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson Rauda Zablah
title: El Salvador’s Bitcoin Paradise Is a Mirage
description: The country’s cryptocurrency is nothing more than authoritarian propaganda.
content: SAN SALVADOR — Bitcoiners — enthusiasts of the world’s most popular cryptocurrency — aren’t supposed to trust government. After all, one of Bitcoin’s premises is to separate money from the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Akron Police Officers Placed on Leave After Fatal Shooting of Black Man
description: A lawyer for the family of the victim, Jayland Walker, said he was struck dozens of times. The Ohio city braced for protests as footage of the shooting is expected to be released Sunday.
content: An unspecified number of police officers in Akron, Ohio, were placed on administrative leave after the fatal shooting of a 25-year-old Black man who the police said continued to drive after they tried to pull him over for an unspecified traffic violation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Iran Earthquake Kills at Least 5, State Media Says
description: Iran’s state news agency said the quake, which did extensive damage to a village, was followed by two more.
content: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — At least five people were killed by a magnitude 6.1 earthquake in southern Iran early Saturday, state media reported. Two other strong quakes later hit the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart and Elias Williams
title: Five Boroughs, Five Days, One Question
description: What’s the vibe right now?
content: “New York City is dead forever,” that one headline declared. But the truth is, even though the coronavirus pulled the emergency brake and forced the city to a screeching halt, New York soon lurched right back into motion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The American Flag Belongs to Me, Too, and This Year I’m Taking It Back
description: Old Glory has become such a strong a feature of Trump rallies that many liberals have all but rejected it.
content: NASHVILLE — We bought our house from a military veteran who hauled his flag out on every officially patriotic occasion. It hung from a flag mount embedded in the bark of a maple tree, and during our first years in the house we followed suit, at least on the Fourth of July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: This regional leader is a symbol of Ukrainian defiance.
description: Vitaliy Kim is the head of the regional military administration in the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
content: To win the war, says Vitaliy Kim, you need to love the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: Yellowstone to Weigh Climate Change Risks When Rebuilding From Flood
description: The country’s oldest national park is considering whether to route its north entrance road away from the Gardner River.
content: HELENA, Mont. — In the shadow of hills and rock walls, the north entrance road at Yellowstone National Park normally traces the river, ferrying visitors from the outside world to a very different one teeming with wildlife and otherworldly geothermal features.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Smart
title: How the Russian Media Spread False Claims About Ukrainian Nazis
description: An analysis of nearly eight million articles about Ukraine from Russian websites shows that references to Nazism have spiked to unprecedented levels during the war.
content: An analysis of nearly eight million articles about Ukraine from Russian websites shows that references to Nazism have spiked to unprecedented levels during the war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Is the ‘Abortion Abolitionist’ Movement?
description: How a fringe faction has started to gain steam post Roe.
content: How a fringe faction has started to gain steam post Roe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Anti-Abortion Victory, but ‘at What Price’?
description: Readers react to a column by Ross Douthat and a guest essay by an anti-abortion advocate.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 2, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 2, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about the Supreme Court ruling that allows the Biden administration to end a Trump-era immigration program that forces asylum seekers at the southwestern border to await approval in Mexico described incorrectly the history of immigration legislation. Congress has made changes to immigration law since 1986, but it has not passed any law to legalize undocumented immigrants since that year.
source.name: The New York Times
